private_information: You organize and standardize action models, predicates, and their roles.
You ensure that variable roles are consistent across all actions (e.g., ?a for object_0 role, ?b for object_1 role, ?c for object_2 role, ?d for object_3 role).
You do not emit PDDL; instead, you produce a clean, structured description that an orchestrator can translate to PDDL.
action_librarian.goal: Derive a precise action schema specification (predicates, parameters, preconditions, add/delete effects) matching the public description.

private_information: You extract object universes, initial facts, and goal facts for each scenario.
You normalize fact names and argument ordering to match the action schema vocabulary.
You do not emit PDDL; instead, you produce a structured scenario bundle that an orchestrator can translate to PDDL.
state_initializer.goal: Prepare normalized initial states and goals for two scenarios using the exact predicates and objects from the public information.

private_information: You assess whether a candidate plan respects action preconditions and propagates effects on the state.
You focus on Scenario 1 which has a provided plan; you provide a step-wise consistency analysis.
You do not emit PDDL; instead, you supply a validation report that the orchestrator may optionally reflect in comments.
plan_checker.goal: Audit the provided plan for Scenario 1 against the action schemas and initial facts, noting any requirement mismatches or confirmations.

private_information: You integrate upstream specifications into a single PDDL domain and two PDDL problems solvable by the Fast Downward planner.
Keep actions exactly as: paltry, sip, clip, wretched, memory, tightfisted.
Use only STRIPS features (and optionally :negative-preconditions if needed); use add/delete lists to model effects.
Ensure predicate names match exactly: hand, cats, texture, vase, next, sneeze, stupendous, collect, spring.
Include objects object_0 through object_14 for both problems.
orchestrator.goal: Produce a final PDDL domain and two PDDL problems that encode the two scenarios for Fast Downward.

public_information: Available parameterized actions: Paltry object_0 object_1 object_2; Sip object_0 object_1 object_2; Clip object_0 object_1 object_2; Wretched object_0 object_1 object_2 object_3; Memory object_0 object_1 object_2; Tightfisted object_0 object_1 object_2.
Predicates (all are boolean): hand(x), cats(x), texture(x), vase(x,y), next(x,y), sneeze(x), stupendous(x), collect(x,y), spring(x).
Action: paltry ?a ?b ?c. Preconditions: hand ?a, cats ?b, texture ?c, vase ?a ?b, next ?b ?c. Add effects: next ?a ?c. Delete effects: vase ?a ?b.
Action: sip ?a ?b ?c. Preconditions: hand ?a, cats ?b, texture ?c, next ?a ?c, next ?b ?c. Add effects: vase ?a ?b. Delete effects: next ?a ?c.
Action: clip ?a ?b ?c. Preconditions: hand ?a, sneeze ?b, texture ?c, next ?b ?c, next ?a ?c. Add effects: vase ?a ?b. Delete effects: next ?a ?c.
Action: wretched ?a ?b ?c ?d. Preconditions: sneeze ?a, texture ?b, texture ?c, stupendous ?d, next ?a ?b, collect ?b ?d, collect ?c ?d. Add effects: next ?a ?c. Delete effects: next ?a ?b.
Action: memory ?a ?b ?c. Preconditions: cats ?a, spring ?b, spring ?c, next ?a ?b. Add effects: next ?a ?c. Delete effects: next ?a ?b.
Action: tightfisted ?a ?b ?c. Preconditions: hand ?a, sneeze ?b, texture ?c, next ?b ?c, vase ?a ?b. Add effects: next ?a ?c. Delete effects: vase ?a ?b.

STATEMENT 1 initial facts: cats object_0; cats object_1; collect object_10 object_3; collect object_11 object_3; collect object_6 object_2; collect object_7 object_2; collect object_8 object_2; collect object_9 object_3; hand object_12; hand object_13; hand object_14; next object_0 object_6; next object_1 object_9; next object_12 object_11; next object_13 object_6; next object_14 object_8; next object_4 object_7; next object_5 object_10; sneeze object_4; sneeze object_5; spring object_6; spring object_9; stupendous object_2; stupendous object_3; texture object_10; texture object_11; texture object_6; texture object_7; texture object_8; texture object_9.
STATEMENT 1 goal facts: next object_12 object_10; next object_13 object_10; next object_14 object_9.

PLAN 1 candidate: wretched object_4 object_7 object_8 object_2; clip object_14 object_4 object_8; wretched object_4 object_8 object_6 object_2; tightfisted object_14 object_4 object_6; sip object_14 object_0 object_6; sip object_13 object_0 object_6; memory object_0 object_6 object_9; paltry object_14 object_0 object_9; paltry object_13 object_0 object_9; wretched object_5 object_10 object_11 object_3; clip object_12 object_5 object_11; wretched object_5 object_11 object_9 object_3; clip object_13 object_5 object_9; wretched object_5 object_9 object_10 object_3; tightfisted object_13 object_5 object_10; tightfisted object_12 object_5 object_10.

STATEMENT 2 initial facts: cats object_0; collect object_10 object_2; collect object_5 object_1; collect object_6 object_1; collect object_7 object_1; collect object_8 object_2; collect object_9 object_2; hand object_11; hand object_12; hand object_13; hand object_14; next object_0 object_8; next object_11 object_10; next object_12 object_5; next object_13 object_7; next object_14 object_9; next object_3 object_6; next object_4 object_9; sneeze object_3; sneeze object_4; spring object_5; spring object_8; stupendous object_1; stupendous object_2; texture object_10; texture object_5; texture object_6; texture object_7; texture object_8; texture object_9.

analyze.system_prompt: You are an expert at formalizing action models and predicates for classical planning. Given the shared public information, distill the predicate vocabulary and parameterized action schemas with exact preconditions and add/delete effects. Keep it implementation-agnostic and do not emit PDDL.
analyze.prompt: Your name is action_librarian. From the public information, enumerate the predicate set and for each action (paltry, sip, clip, wretched, memory, tightfisted) list parameters (?a, ?b, ?c, ?d as needed) with their roles and specify preconditions, add effects, and delete effects precisely. Use compact, structured prose or JSON-like formatting. Do not output PDDL.

structure.system_prompt: You are an expert at extracting scenario data for planning problems. Normalize the object set, initial facts, and goals for two scenarios using the exact predicate names found in the public information. Do not emit PDDL.
structure.prompt: Your name is state_initializer. Build a structured bundle containing: 1) objects: object_0..object_14; 2) scenario_1: initial facts and goals exactly as listed; 3) scenario_2: initial facts and goals exactly as listed. Preserve fact names and argument order. Do not output PDDL.

audit.system_prompt: You are an expert in plan validation. Using the public action definitions, check the given candidate plan for Scenario 1 against the initial facts and goals. Report step-by-step whether preconditions hold and how the state changes. Do not emit PDDL.
audit.prompt: Your name is plan_checker. Validate the PLAN 1 candidate action by action. If a step requires facts not yet established, call it out; otherwise, confirm and propagate the add/delete effects. Conclude with whether the final state meets all Scenario 1 goals. Do not output PDDL.

compile.system_prompt: You are an expert in multi-instance classical planning. Integrate the action schema and two scenario specifications to produce a single PDDL domain and two PDDL problem files for the Fast Downward planner. Use STRIPS-compatible constructs (and optionally :negative-preconditions if strictly necessary). Keep action names exactly as paltry, sip, clip, wretched, memory, tightfisted and predicate names exactly as hand, cats, texture, vase, next, sneeze, stupendous, collect, spring. Include the full object list object_0 through object_14. Enclose the domain between <domain>...</domain> and each problem between <problem id='1'>...</problem> and <problem id='2'>...</problem>.
compile.prompt: Coordinate the inputs, resolve any discrepancies, and output only the final PDDL artifacts. The domain must encode the six actions with the preconditions and effects described in the public information. Problem 1 and Problem 2 must include the exact initial facts and goals from STATEMENT 1 and STATEMENT 2, respectively. Target Fast Downward: prefer :strips and use add/delete lists; avoid unsupported features. If you include a solution hint, put it in comments; otherwise, provide only the PDDL wrapped in the specified tags.
